advanced-guides/security-best-practices.name: security-best-practices
advanced-guides/security-best-practices.content:
Security Best Practices


Security is of utmost importance when dealing with payment transactions. lomi. provides a secure payment orchestration platform, but it's also crucial to follow security best practices in your own integration to protect your customers' sensitive information.

Secure Communication


Always use HTTPS for all communication between your server and the lomi. API. This ensures that all data transmitted is encrypted and protected from eavesdropping.

Protect Your API Keys


Keep your lomi. API keys secure and never expose them in client-side code or publicly accessible repositories. Store them securely on your server and use environment variables to load them into your application.

Validate and Sanitize User Input


Validate and sanitize all user input before sending it to the lomi. API. This helps prevent injection attacks and ensures that the data sent to lomi. is in the expected format.

Use Secure Authentication Methods


When authenticating your customers, use secure methods such as OAuth 2.0 or JWT tokens. Avoid sending sensitive information, such as passwords, in plain text.

Implement Secure Webhook Endpoints


When configuring webhook endpoints to receive notifications from lomi., ensure that they are secure and accessible only to lomi.. Validate the webhook signatures to verify the authenticity of the requests.

Regularly Update Your Integration


Keep your lomi. integration code up-to-date with the latest security patches and API updates. Regularly monitor the lomi. changelog and update your code accordingly.

Limit Access to Sensitive Data


Restrict access to sensitive customer and transaction data to only those who need it. Implement proper access controls and logging to detect and prevent unauthorized access.

Educate Your Team


Educate your team about security best practices and ensure that everyone understands their role in keeping your integration secure. Regularly review and update your security policies and procedures.

Monitor and Audit Your Systems


Implement monitoring and auditing mechanisms to detect and respond to security incidents promptly. Regularly review your logs and access records to identify any suspicious activities.

By following these security best practices, you can ensure that your lomi. integration is secure and protect your customers' sensitive information.

get-started/lomi-basics/create-merchant-.name: create-merchant-account
get-started/lomi-basics/create-merchant-.content:
Creating your merchant account


To start using lomi., you first need to create an account. 

1. Visit the [lomi. website]( and click on the "Sign Up" button.
2. Get through the KYC process and fill in your business details, including your company name, contact information, and the payment methods you want to support.
3. Agree to our terms of service.
4. You will receive a confirmation email. Click the link in the email to verify your account.

Congratulations! You have successfully created your lomi. merchant account. You can now log in to your dashboard and start configuring your payment integration.

get-started/lomi-basics/process-transact.name: process-transactions
get-started/lomi-basics/process-transact.content:
Processing Transactions


With lomi. integrated into your application or website, you can start processing transactions.

1. When a customer initiates a payment on your website or app, send a payment request to lomi. using the appropriate API endpoint or SDK method.

2. lomi. will handle the payment flow, securely collecting the customer's payment details and processing the transaction through the selected payment method.

3. You will receive a response indicating the status of the transaction (success, failure, or pending).

4. Use webhooks to receive real-time notifications about transaction updates and status changes.

5. Manage and track your transactions through the lomi. dashboard, which provides detailed reporting and analytics.

lomi. ensures secure and reliable payment processing, with built-in fraud detection and PCI DSS compliance.

For more information on transaction processing and best practices, refer to the [Transaction Processing Guide](../transactions/overview). Please note that you can also use lomi. in a Low-code and No-code set-up.

get-started/lomi-basics/setup-payment-me.name: setup-payment-methods
get-started/lomi-basics/setup-payment-me.content:
Setting Up Payment Methods


After creating your merchant account, the next step is to set up the payment methods you want to offer to your customers.

1. Log in to your dashboard.
2. Navigate to the "Payment Methods" section.
3. Select the payment method you want to add (e.g., MTN, Wave or Orange Mobile Money).

Repeat these steps for each payment method you want to support. lomi. will handle the integration with the respective payment providers automatically.

Feel free to customize your checkout experience, set up webhooks for real-time notifications, and explore other features available in your dashboard.

get-started/lomi-basics/sign-up.name: sign-up
get-started/lomi-basics/sign-up.content:
Getting Started with lomi.


To start using lomi. for your payment processing needs, follow these steps:

1. **Sign up**: Visit [lomi.'s website]( and create a merchant account.

2. **Set up payment methods**: Configure the payment methods you want to support in your lomi. dashboard.

3. **Integrate with your application**: Use lomi.'s API or SDKs to integrate payment processing into your application. Refer to the [Integration Guide](../integration/getting-started) for detailed instructions.

4. **Test your integration**: Use lomi.'s testing environment to simulate transactions and ensure your integration is working as expected.

5. **Go live**: Once you've thoroughly tested your integration, switch to live mode and start processing real transactions.

lomi. provides comprehensive documentation, SDKs, and support to help you get started quickly and smoothly.

get-started/variables/api-keys.name: api-keys
get-started/variables/api-keys.content:
API Keys


API keys are used to authenticate your integration with the lomi. API. It's essential to keep your API keys secure and manage them effectively.

Creating API Keys


To create an API key:

1. Log in to your lomi. account and navigate to the "Settings" page.
2. Click on the "API Keys" tab.
3. Click the "Create API Key" button.
4. Enter a name for your API key and select the appropriate permissions.
5. Click "Create" to generate your API key.
6. Copy and save your Key!

Using API Keys


To use your API key, include it in the `Authorization` header of your API requests:

```bash
Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY
```

In your integration code, you can store your API key as an environment variable and reference it using the `{{ENV_VAR_NAME}}` syntax:

```javascript
const apiKey = '{{LOMI_API_KEY}}';
const headers = {
  'Authorization': `Bearer ${apiKey}`,
  'Content-Type': 'application/json'
};
```

Best Practices


- Keep your API keys secure and never share them with anyone.
- Regularly rotate your API keys to minimize the risk of unauthorized access.
- Use environment variables to store your API keys instead of hardcoding them in your integration code.
- Restrict the permissions of your API keys to the minimum required for your integration to function.

By following these best practices, you can ensure the security and integrity of your lomi. integration.

get-started/variables/overview.name: overview
get-started/variables/overview.content:
Variables


Variables in lomi. allow you to store and manage dynamic values that can be used across your payment integration setup. This feature enhances flexibility, maintainability, and security by enabling you to manage sensitive data, such as API keys, in a centralized manner.

lomi. supports the use of variables, specifically API keys, to authenticate and secure your integration with the lomi. API.

- [API Keys](./api-keys): Manage your API keys securely and use them to authenticate your requests to the lomi. API.

By leveraging variables, you can keep your integration setup clean, maintainable, and secure, while easily managing your API credentials.

git-integration/best-practices.name: best-practices
git-integration/best-practices.content:
Best Practices for Git Integration


When integrating lomi. with your application, follow these best practices to ensure a smooth and secure development process:

1. **Use a version control system**: Always store your integration code and configuration files in a version control system like Git. This allows you to track changes, collaborate with your team, and maintain a history of your integration setup.

2. **Keep sensitive information separate**: Never store sensitive information like API keys, secrets, and credentials in version control. Instead, use environment variables or secure key management systems to handle sensitive data.

3. **Ignore generated files**: Add generated files and directories (e.g., `node_modules`, `.next`, `.env`) to your `.gitignore` file to prevent them from being committed to your repository.

4. **Commit frequently**: Make small, focused commits that cover a single logical change. This makes it easier to understand the history of your codebase and revert changes if needed.

5. **Write descriptive commit messages**: Use clear and concise commit messages that explain the purpose of each change. This helps other team members (and your future self) understand the history of your codebase.

By following these best practices, you can maintain a clean and organized codebase while effectively collaborating with your team.

git-integration/bounty-program.name: bounty-program
git-integration/bounty-program.content:
Bounty Program


To encourage and reward contributions to lomi., we have established a bounty program. Developers can earn rewards for completing specific tasks, such as:

- Developing new payment integrations
- Implementing new features
- Solving technical issues and bugs
- Improving the platform's security
- Enhancing documentation and tutorials

Available Bounties


Check out our [Bounties Board]( on GitHub to see the list of available bounties and their respective rewards.

Claiming a Bounty


To claim a bounty, follow these steps:

1. Choose a bounty from the [Bounties Board]( that you want to work on.
2. Comment on the issue, expressing your interest in taking on the bounty.
3. The lomi. team will review your request and assign the bounty to you if approved.
4. Work on the bounty, following the contributing guidelines and any specific requirements mentioned in the issue.
5. Submit a pull request with your solution, referencing the bounty issue.
6. The lomi. team will review your pull request and merge it if it meets the requirements.
7. Once your pull request is merged, you will receive the bounty reward.

Bounty Rewards


Bounty rewards are paid out in USD via PayPal or other agreed-upon payment methods. The reward amount for each bounty is specified on the [Bounties Board](

We reserve the right to modify the bounty program and reward amounts at any time.

Happy bounty hunting!

git-integration/branching-strategy.name: branching-strategy
git-integration/branching-strategy.content:
Branching Strategy


When working on your lomi. integration, it's important to use a consistent branching strategy to manage your codebase. We recommend the following branching strategy:

- `main` (or `master`): The main branch that contains the stable, production-ready code.
- `develop`: The branch that contains the latest development changes that are ready for testing.
- `feature/*`: Branches used for developing new features. These branches should be created from the `develop` branch and merged back into `develop` when the feature is complete.
- `bugfix/*`: Branches used for fixing bugs. These branches should be created from the `develop` branch and merged back into `develop` when the bug is fixed.
- `release/*`: Branches used for preparing a new release. These branches should be created from the `develop` branch and merged into both `main` and `develop` when the release is ready.
- `hotfix/*`: Branches used for fixing critical bugs in production. These branches should be created from the `main` branch and merged into both `main` and `develop` when the hotfix is complete.

By using this branching strategy, you can ensure that your codebase remains stable and organized while allowing for parallel development of features and bug fixes.

git-integration/code-of-conduct.name: code-of-conduct
git-integration/code-of-conduct.content:
Code of Conduct


As contributors and maintainers of the lomi. project, we pledge to create a welcoming and inclusive environment for everyone, regardless of age, body size, disability, ethnicity, gender identity and expression, level of experience, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.

Our Standards


Examples of behavior that contributes to creating a positive environment include:

- Using welcoming and inclusive language
- Being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences
- Gracefully accepting constructive criticism
- Focusing on what is best for the community
- Showing empathy towards other community members

Examples of unacceptable behavior by participants include:

- The use of sexualized language or imagery and unwelcome sexual attention or advances
- Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
- Public or private harassment
- Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or electronic address, without explicit permission
- Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting

Our Responsibilities


Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying the standards of acceptable behavior and are expected to take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any instances of unacceptable behavior.

Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, or to ban temporarily or permanently any contributor for other behaviors that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.

Scope


This Code of Conduct applies both within project spaces and in public spaces when an individual is representing the project or its community.

Enforcement


Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported by contacting the project team at [conduct@lomi.africa](mailto:conduct@lomi.africa). All complaints will be reviewed and investigated and will result in a response that is deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances. The project team is obligated to maintain confidentiality with regard to the reporter of an incident. Further details of specific enforcement policies may be posted separately.

Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other members of the project's leadership.

git-integration/code-reviews.name: code-reviews
git-integration/code-reviews.content:
Code Reviews


Code reviews are an essential part of maintaining a high-quality codebase. When working on your lomi. integration, make sure to:

1. **Create pull requests**: When a feature or bug fix is complete, create a pull request to merge the changes into the `develop` branch.

2. **Review code changes**: Have at least one other team member review the code changes in the pull request. Look for potential bugs, security issues, and opportunities for improvement.

3. **Discuss and address feedback**: Use the pull request comments to discuss any issues or suggestions for improvement. Make sure to address all feedback before merging the changes.

4. **Test thoroughly**: Before merging a pull request, make sure to thoroughly test the changes to ensure that they work as expected and do not introduce any new bugs.

By incorporating code reviews into your development process, you can catch potential issues early and ensure that your codebase remains maintainable and secure.

git-integration/contributing-guidelines.name: contributing-guidelines
git-integration/contributing-guidelines.content:
Contributing Guidelines


To ensure a smooth and effective collaboration, please follow these guidelines when contributing to lomi.:

1. **Code Style**: Follow the existing code style and conventions used in the lomi. codebase. We use [Prettier]( for code formatting and [ESLint]( for linting.

2. **Documentation**: Update the relevant documentation when making changes to the codebase. This includes inline comments, README files, and API documentation.

3. **Testing**: Write unit tests for new features and bug fixes. Ensure that all tests pass before submitting a pull request.

4. **Commit Messages**: Write clear and descriptive commit messages that explain the purpose of your changes. Use the present tense and imperative mood (e.g., "Add feature" instead of "Added feature").

5. **Pull Requests**: Keep pull requests focused on a single feature, bug fix, or improvement. Provide a detailed description of your changes and reference any relevant issues.

6. **Code Reviews**: Be open to feedback and constructive criticism during the code review process. Address any comments or suggestions made by the maintainers.

7. **Licensing**: By contributing to lomi., you agree that your contributions will be licensed under the [MIT License](

We appreciate your adherence to these guidelines and your efforts to make lomi. a better platform for everyone.

git-integration/using-cli.name: using-cli
git-integration/using-cli.content:
Using Git CLI for Collaboration


When collaborating on your lomi. integration using Git, you can use the command-line interface (CLI) to perform various Git operations. This allows you to manage your integration code and configurations effectively.

Initializing a Git Repository


To get started, initialize a Git repository in the directory where your integration code and configuration files are stored:

```bash
git init
```

Staging and Committing Changes


After making changes to your integration code or configurations, stage the changes using the `git add` command:

```bash
git add .
```

Then, commit the changes with a descriptive message:

```bash
git commit -m "Update payment provider configuration"
```

Pushing Changes to a Remote Repository


To collaborate with your team, push your changes to a remote repository:

```bash
git push origin main
```

Replace `main` with the appropriate branch name if you're using a different branching strategy.

Pulling Changes from a Remote Repository


To get the latest changes made by your team members, pull the changes from the remote repository:

```bash
git pull origin main
```

Again, replace `main` with the appropriate branch name if necessary.

Resolving Merge Conflicts


If you encounter merge conflicts when pulling changes, you'll need to resolve them manually. Open the conflicting files, make the necessary changes, and then stage and commit the resolved files:

```bash
git add resolved_file.js
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflicts"
```

Best Practices


- Commit frequently with descriptive messages
- Use branches for developing new features or configurations
- Regularly pull changes from the remote repository to stay up-to-date
- Resolve merge conflicts carefully and communicate with your team

By using the Git CLI effectively and following best practices, you can collaborate smoothly with your team on your lomi. integration.

git-integration/versioning.name: versioning
git-integration/versioning.content:
Versioning


Versioning your lomi. integration is important for tracking changes and managing releases. We recommend using semantic versioning (SemVer) for your integration.

With SemVer, each version number consists of three parts: `MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH`.

- `MAJOR`: Increment this when you make incompatible API changes.
- `MINOR`: Increment this when you add functionality in a backwards-compatible manner.
- `PATCH`: Increment this when you make backwards-compatible bug fixes.

When preparing a new release:

1. **Update the version number**: Increment the appropriate part of the version number based on the changes included in the release.

2. **Create a release branch**: Create a new branch from `develop` with the name `release/X.Y.Z`, where `X.Y.Z` is the new version number.

3. **Finalize the release**: Make any necessary final changes to the release branch, such as updating documentation or fixing last-minute bugs.

4. **Merge the release branch**: Once the release is ready, merge the release branch into both `main` and `develop`.

5. **Tag the release**: Create a new Git tag with the version number (e.g., `v1.2.3`) to mark the release point in your codebase.

By following a consistent versioning scheme and release process, you can make it easier to manage your integration and communicate changes to your team and users.

introduction/manifesto.name: manifesto
introduction/manifesto.content:
Manifesto


The time has come to transform payment processing across Africa.

We believe that accepting payments shouldn't be complex, regardless of where you operate or what payment methods your customers prefer. The fragmented payment landscape in Africa creates unnecessary barriers and friction for businesses trying to grow.

lomi. addresses these challenges with an open approach to payment orchestration. We believe that:

- **Payment processing should be simple**: One integration to accept all the payment methods you want!
- **Security is non-negotiable**: Every transaction is protected with industry-leading security measures
- **Innovation should be accessible**: Advanced features like fraud detection and analytics are available to all businesses
- **Integration should be seamless**: Adding new payment methods is straightforward and hassle-free
- **Compliance is built-in**: Meeting regulatory requirements is part of our platform's foundation

We envision a Continent where any business can easily accept payments from their customers, using any payment method, without worrying about the complexity behind the scenes.

Join us in our mission to simplify payment processing across Africa.

introduction/what-is-lomi.name: what-is-lomi
introduction/what-is-lomi.content:
What is lomi.?


lomi. is a unified, open-source payment orchestration platform built to transform payment processing across Africa. We seamlessly integrate multiple payment providers and related payment methods while providing a comprehensive solution for merchants.

We aim to solve two core challenges:

**Payment Complexity**


lomi.'s mission is to simplify the complex landscape of African payments through a unified platform that:

- Integrates multiple payment methods (Credit cards, MTN Momo, Wave, Orange Money â€” and counting!)
- Provides comprehensive reporting and analytics
- Offers great and highly customizable checkout experiences
- Ensures secure, reliable payment processing

> *You can get started by creating an account on [lomi.](

**Security and Compliance**


Payment processing demands the highest levels of security and compliance. lomi. is built with:

- Robust fraud detection and prevention
- Secure tokenization and data storage
- Comprehensive audit trails

The platform is designed with security-first principles, ensuring that both merchants and their customers can transact with confidence.

lomi-cli/overview.name: overview
lomi-cli/overview.content:
lomi. CLI


The lomi. CLI allows you to interact with your lomi. account and perform various tasks related to your payment integration setup using simple command-line commands.

This makes it easier to manage your payment integrations, test your setup in different environments, automate your testing process, and deploy the applicaiton more easily.

Installation


To install the lomi. CLI, use the package manager of your choice, such as NPM:

```bash copy
npm install -g @lomi/cli
```

Authentication


To use the lomi. CLI, you need to authenticate with your lomi. account. You can do this by setting the `LOMI_API_KEY` environment variable to your API key:

```bash copy
export LOMI_API_KEY=your_api_key_here
```

Alternatively, you can pass the API key as a command-line argument using the `--api-key` flag:

```bash copy
lomi --api-key your_api_key_here command
```

Commands


`lomi setup`


The `setup` command helps you set up your lomi. integration by guiding you through the process of creating a merchant account, setting up payment methods, and configuring your integration settings.

```bash copy
lomi setup
```

`lomi test`


The `test` command allows you to test your payment integration by simulating transactions and verifying that your integration is working as expected.

```bash copy
lomi test
```

`lomi transactions`


The `transactions` command allows you to view and manage your transactions. You can list recent transactions, view transaction details, and perform actions such as refunds or captures.

```bash copy
lomi transactions list
lomi transactions view 
lomi transactions refund 
lomi transactions capture 
```

`lomi webhooks`


The `webhooks` command allows you to manage your webhooks. You can list your registered webhooks, create new webhooks, and delete existing webhooks.

```bash copy
lomi webhooks list
lomi webhooks create --url  --events 
lomi webhooks delete 
```

Support


If you encounter any issues or have any questions or feedback, please contact our support team at [support@lomi.africa](mailto:support@lomi.africa) or visit our [documentation]( for more information.
